title: MRCV
text: Provides functions analyzing association one single response categorical variable (SRCV) one multiple response categorical variable (MRCV), two three MRCVs. modified Pearson chi-square statistic can used test marginal independence one two MRCV case, general loglinear modeling approach can used examine various structures association two three MRCV case. Bootstrap- asymptotic-based standardized residuals model-predicted odds ratios available, addition descriptive information. Statisical methods implemented described Bilder et al. (2000) doi:10.1080/03610910008813665>, Bilder Loughin (2004) <doi:10.1111/j.0006-341X.2004.00147.x>, Bilder Loughin (2007) <doi:10.1080/03610920600974419>, Koziol Bilder (2014) <https://journal.r-project.org/articles/RJ-2014-014/.

title: Test for Marginal Independence — MI.test
text: MI.test function offers three approaches testing multiple marginal independence (MMI) one SRCV one MRCV, simultaneous pairwise marginal independence (SPMI) two MRCVs.

title: Test for Marginal Independence — MI.test
code: MI.test(   data,   I,   J,   type = "all",   B = 1999,   B.max = B,   summary.data = FALSE,   add.constant = 0.5,   plot.hist = FALSE,   print.status = TRUE )

title: Test for Marginal Independence — MI.test
text: data summary.data = FALSE: data frame containing raw data rows correspond individual item response vectors, columns correspond items, W1, ..., WI Y1, ..., YJ (order). summary.data = TRUE: data frame containing 4 columns generically named W, Y, yj, count (one MRCV case), 5 columns named W, Y, wi, yj, count (two MRCV case). number items corresponding row variable W.  = 1 one MRCV case. J number items corresponding column variable Y. type character string specifying one following approaches testing MI: "boot" specifies nonparametric bootstrap procedure; "rs2" specifies Rao-Scott second-order adjustment; "bon" specifies Bonferroni adjustment; "" specifies three approaches. B desired number bootstrap resamples. B.max maximum number bootstrap resamples.  resample thrown least one J (one MRCV case) IxJ (two MRCV case) contingency tables correct dimension; MI.test uses first B valid resamples valid resamples number less B. summary.data logical value indicating whether data summary file containing item response data instead raw data. type = "bon" available summary.data = TRUE. add.constant positive constant added zero marginal cell counts. plot.hist logical value indicating whether plots emprical bootstrap sampling distributions provided. print.status logical value indicating whether bootstrap progress updates provided.

title: Test for Marginal Independence — MI.test
text: — MI.test returns list containing least general, list containing following objects: data: original data frame supplied data argument. : original value supplied argument. J: original value supplied J argument. summary.data: original value supplied summary.data argument. X.sq.S: modified Pearson statistic; NA least one J (one MRCV case) IxJ (two MRCV case) contingency tables correct dimension. X.sq.S.ij: matrix containing individual Pearson statistics. — type = "boot", primary list additionally includes boot, list containing following objects: B.use: number bootstrap resamples used. B.discard: number bootstrap resamples discarded due least one contingency table incorrect dimension. p.value.boot: bootstrap p-value test MMI SPMI. p.combo.min.boot: bootstrap p-value minimum p-value combination method. p.combo.prod.boot: bootstrap p-value product p-value combination method. X.sq.S.star: numeric vector containing modified Pearson statistics calculated resample. X.sq.S.ij.star: matrix containing individual Pearson statistics calculated resample. p.combo.min.star: numeric vector containing minimum p-value calculated resample. p.combo.prod.star: numeric vector containing product p-value calculated resample. — type = "rs2", primary list additionally includes rs2, list containing following objects: X.sq.S.rs2: Rao-Scott second-order adjusted Pearson statistic. df.rs2: degrees freedom testing second-order Rao-Scott adjusted Pearson statistic. p.value.rs2: p-value based Rao-Scott second-order adjustment. — type = "bon", primary list additionally includes bon, list containing following objects: p.value.bon: Bonferroni adjusted p-value test MMI SPMI. X.sq.S.ij.p.bon: matrix containing Bonferroni adjusted p-values individual Pearson statistics. — type = "", list includes objects. — MI.stat returns list containing following objects: X.sq.S: Defined . X.sq.S.ij: Defined . valid.margins: number contingency tables correct dimension.

title: Test for Marginal Independence — MI.test
text: MI.test function calls MI.stat calculate modified Pearson statistic (see Bilder, Loughin, Nettleton (2000) Bilder Loughin (2004)), performs testing MMI SPMI.  Three sets testing methods implemented: nonparametric bootstrap resamples null hypothesis independently sampling W Y vectors replacement observed data.  Fixed row counts (.e., fixed counts level SRCV) maintained one MRCV case.  modified Pearson statistic calculated resample. addition, bootstrap p-value combination methods available take advantage modified Pearson statistic's decomposition J (one MRCV case) IxJ (two MRCV case) individual Pearson statistics.  minimum product p-values combination resample. Rao-Scott approach applies second-order adjustment modified Pearson statistic sampling distribution.  Formulas provided Appendix Bilder, Loughin, Nettleton (2000) Bilder Loughin (2004). Note test can conservative times. Bonferroni adjustment multiplies p-value (using standard chi-square approximation) individual Pearson statistics J (one MRCV case) IxJ (two MRCV case).  resulting p-value greater 1 multiplication, set value 1.  overall p-value test minimum adjusted p-values.  Note Bonferroni adjustment tends produce overly conservative test number individual Pearson statistics large. Agresti Liu (1999) discuss marginal logit model approach uses generalized estimation equations (GEE) test MMI.  shown example given , approach can performed via functions available geepack package.  However, Bilder, Loughin, Nettleton (2000) caution Wald test produced approach hold correct size, particularly sample size large marginal probabilities small.

title: Test for Marginal Independence — MI.test
text: Agresti, . Liu, .-M. (1999) Modeling categorical variable allowing arbitrarily many category choices.  Biometrics, 55, 936–943. Bilder, C. Loughin, T. (2004) Testing marginal independence two categorical variables multiple responses.  Biometrics, 36, 433–451. Bilder, C., Loughin, T., Nettleton, D. (2000) Multiple marginal independence testing pick /c variables.  Communications Statistics–Theory Methods, 29, 1285–1316.

title: Test for Marginal Independence — MI.test

what: Methods for Analyzing Multiple Response Categorical Variables — MRCV-package
title: Methods for Analyzing Multiple Response Categorical Variables — MRCV-package
text: Provides functions analyzing association one single response categorical variable (SRCV) one multiple response categorical variable (MRCV), two three MRCVs.  modified Pearson chi-square statistic can used test marginal independence one two MRCV case, general loglinear modeling approach can used examine various structures association two three MRCV case.  Bootstrap- asymptotic-based standardized residuals model-predicted odds ratios available, addition descriptive information. Notation: two three MRCV case, define row variable, W, column variable, Y, strata variable, Z, MRCVs binary items (.e., categories) Wi = 1, ..., , Yj j = 1, ..., J, Zk k = 1, ..., K, respectively.  Define marginal count number subjects responded (Wi = , Yj = b, Zk = c) , b, c belonging set {0, 1}.  one MRCV case, let W SRCV = 1 '' corresponds one r levels W, let Y MRCV previously defined. Format Data Frame: Many functions require data frame containing raw data structured n rows correspond individual item response vectors, columns correspond items, W1, ..., WI, Y1, ..., YJ, Z1, ..., ZK (order). functions use summary version raw data frame (converted automatically without need user action) formatted rx2J rows 4 columns generically named W, Y, yj, count (one MRCV case), 2Ix2J rows 5 columns named W, Y, wi, yj, count (two MRCV case), 2Ix2Jx2K rows 7 columns named W, Y, Z, wi, yj, zk, count (three MRCV case). column named count contains marginal counts defined . Descriptive Functions: Users can call item.response.table function obtain cross-tabulation positive negative responses combination items, marginal.table function obtain cross-tabulation positive responses. Functions Test Marginal Independence: Methods proposed Agresti Liu (1999), Bilder Loughin (2004), Bilder, Loughin, Nettleton (2000), Thomas Decady (2004) implemented using MI.test function.  function calculates modified Pearson chi-square statistic can used test multiple marginal independence (MMI; one MRCV case) simultaneous pairwise marginal independence (SPMI; two MRCV case).  MMI test whether SRCV, W, marginally independent Yj, modified statistic sum J Pearson statistics used test independence (W, Yj) pair.  SPMI test whether Wi pairwise independent Yj, modified statistic sum IxJ Pearson statistics used test independence (Wi, Yj) pair.  asymptotic distribution modified statistics linear combination independent chi-square(1) random variables, traditional methods analyzing association categorical variables W Y inappropriate.  MI.test function offers three sets testing methods: nonparametric bootstrap approach, Rao-Scott second-order adjustment, Bonferroni adjustment, can used conjunction modified statistic construct appropriate test independence. Functions Performing Regression Modeling: Regression modeling methods described Bilder Loughin (2007) implemented using genloglin methods summary.genloglin, residuals.genloglin, anova.genloglin, predict.genloglin.  genloglin function provides parameter estimates Rao-Scott adjusted standard errors models involving two three MRCVs.  anova.genloglin function offers second-order Rao-Scott bootstrap adjusted model comparison goodness--fit (Pearson LRT) statistics.  residuals.genloglin predict.genloglin functions provide bootstrap- asymptotic-based standardized Pearson residuals model-based odds ratios, respectively. General Notes: Rao-Scott adjustments may feasible total number MRCV items large.  case, error message returned describing memory allocation issue.

title: Methods for Analyzing Multiple Response Categorical Variables — MRCV-package
text: Agresti, . Liu, .-M. (1999) Modeling categorical variable allowing arbitrarily many category choices.  Biometrics, 55, 936–943. Bilder, C. Loughin, T. (2004) Testing marginal independence two categorical variables multiple responses.  Biometrics, 36, 433–451. Bilder, C. Loughin, T. (2007) Modeling association two categorical variables allow multiple category choices. Communications Statistics–Theory Methods, 36, 433–451. Bilder, C., Loughin, T., Nettleton, D. (2000) Multiple marginal independence testing pick /c variables.  Communications Statistics–Theory Methods, 29, 1285–1316. Koziol, N. Bilder, C. (2014) MRCV: package analyzing categorical variables multiple response options.  R Journal, 6, 144–150. Thomas, D. Decady, Y. (2004) Testing association using multiple response survey data: Approximate procedures based Rao-Scott approach.  International Journal Testing, 4, 43–59.

title: Methods for Analyzing Multiple Response Categorical Variables — MRCV-package
text: Natalie Koziol, Chris Bilder Maintainer: Chris Bilder <bilder@unl.edu>

what: Perform MRCV Model Comparison Tests — anova.genloglin
title: Perform MRCV Model Comparison Tests — anova.genloglin
text: anova.genloglin method function offers second-order Rao-Scott bootstrap adjusted model comparison goodness--fit (Pearson LRT) statistics appropriate evaluating models estimated genloglin function.

title: Perform MRCV Model Comparison Tests — anova.genloglin
code: # S3 method for class 'genloglin' anova(   object,   model.HA = "saturated",   type = "all",   gof = TRUE,   print.status = TRUE,   ... )

title: Perform MRCV Model Comparison Tests — anova.genloglin
text: object object class 'genloglin' produced genloglin function. model.HA two MRCV case, character string specifying one following models compared null model (null model nested within alternative model): "homogeneous" (homogeneous association model), "w.main" (w-main effects model), "y.main" (y-main effects model), "wy.main" (w- y-main effects model), "saturated".  Alternatively, user-supplied formula can specified.  three MRCV case, "saturated" user-supplied formulas accepted. type character string specifying one following approaches performing adjusted model comparison tests: "boot" specifies bootstrapping procedure; "rs2" specifies Rao-Scott second-order adjustment; "" specifies approaches. gof logical value indicating whether goodness--fit statistics calculated addition model comparison statistics.  model.HA = "saturated", model comparison statistics goodness--fit statistics identical, one set statistics presented. print.status logical value indicating whether bootstrap progress updates provided. ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Perform MRCV Model Comparison Tests — anova.genloglin
text: — list containing least following objects: original.arg test.statistics. original.arg list containing following objects: model: original model specified call genloglin function. model.HA: alternative model specified model.HA argument. gof: original value supplied gof argument. test.statistics list containing least following objects: Pearson.chisq: Pearson model comparison statistic calculated using observed data. lrt: LRT model comparison statistic calculated using observed data. gof = TRUE, test.statistics additionally contains Pearson.chisq.gof: Pearson goodness--fit statistic calculated using observed data. lrt.gof: LRT goodness--fit statistic calculated using observed data. — type = "boot", primary list additionally includes boot.results, list containing least following objects: B.use: number bootstrap resamples used. B.discard: number bootstrap resamples discarded due least one item positive negative responses. p.chisq.boot: bootstrap p-value Pearson model comparison test. p.lrt.boot: bootstrap p-value LRT model comparison test. gof = TRUE, boot.results additionally contains p.chisq.gof.boot: bootstrap p-value Pearson goodness--fit test. p.lrt.gof.boot: bootstrap p-value LRT goodness--fit test. — type = "rs2", primary list additionally includes rs.results, list includes least Pearson.chisq.rs lrt.rs. Pearson.chisq.rs list containing following objects: Pearson.chisq.rs: Rao-Scott second-order adjusted Pearson model comparison statistic. df: Rao-Scott second-order adjusted degrees freedom model comparison statistic. p.value: p-value Rao-Scott second-order adjusted Pearson model comparison test. lrt.rs list containing following objects: lrt.rs: Rao-Scott second-order adjusted LRT model comparison statistic. df: df given . p.value: p-value Rao-Scott second-order adjusted LRT model comparison test. gof = TRUE, rs.results additionally includes Pearson.chisq.gof.rs lrt.gof.rs. Pearson.chisq.gof.rs list containing following objects: Pearson.chisq.gof.rs: Rao-Scott second-order adjusted Pearson goodness--fit statistic. df: df given . p.value: p-value Rao-Scott second-order adjusted Pearson goodness--fit test. lrt.gof.rs list containing following objects: lrt.gof.rs: Rao-Scott second-order adjusted LRT goodness--fit statistic. df: df given . p.value: p-value Rao-Scott second-order adjusted LRT goodness--fit test. — type = "", original list includes boot.results rs.results output.

title: Perform MRCV Model Comparison Tests — anova.genloglin
text: Rao-Scott approach applies second-order adjustment model comparison statistic sampling distribution.  Formulas provided Appendix Bilder Loughin (2007). bootstrap approach empirically estimates sampling distribution model comparison statistic.  Gange's (1995) method generating correlated binary data used taking resamples null hypothesis.  Bootstrap results available boot = TRUE call genloglin function.

text: Bilder, C. Loughin, T. (2007) Modeling association two categorical variables allow multiple category choices. Communications Statistics–Theory Methods, 36, 433–451. Gange, S. (1995) Generating multivariate categorical variates using iterative proportional fitting algorithm.  American Statistician, 49, 134–138.

what: Data for One SRCV and One MRCV from the Kansas Farmer Survey — farmer1
title: Data for One SRCV and One MRCV from the Kansas Farmer Survey — farmer1
text: Responses one SRCV one MRCV survey Kansas farmers. data first examined Loughin Scherer (1998) subsequently examined papers Agresti Liu (1999) Bilder, Loughin, Nettleton (2000).

title: Data for One SRCV and One MRCV from the Kansas Farmer Survey — farmer1
text: data frame contains following 6 columns: Column 1, labeled Ed, corresponds respondent's highest attained level education.  total r = 5 levels education represented data. 1: High school 2: Vocational school 3: 2-Year college 4: 4-Year college 5: Columns 2-6 correspond response categories question "primary sources veterinary information?"  Binary responses (1 = Yes, 0 = ) provided category. Y1: Professional consultant Y2: Veterinarian Y3: State local extension service Y4: Magazines Y5: Feed companies representatives

what: Model the Association Among Two or Three MRCVs — genloglin
title: Model the Association Among Two or Three MRCVs — genloglin
text: genloglin function uses generalized loglinear modeling approach estimate association among two three MRCVs.  Standard errors adjusted using second-order Rao-Scott approach.

title: Model the Association Among Two or Three MRCVs — genloglin
code: genloglin(   data,   I,   J,   K = NULL,   model,   add.constant = 0.5,   boot = TRUE,   B = 1999,   B.max = B,   print.status = TRUE )

title: Model the Association Among Two or Three MRCVs — genloglin
text: data data frame containing raw data rows correspond individual item response vectors, columns correspond binary items, W1, ..., WI, Y1, ..., YJ, Z1, ..., ZK (order). number items corresponding row variable W. J number items corresponding column variable Y. K number items corresponding strata variable Z. model two MRCV case, character string specifying one following models: "spmi" (complete independence model), "homogeneous" (homogeneous association model), "w.main" (w-main effects model), "y.main" (y-main effects model), "wy.main" (w-main y-main effects model), "saturated".  Alternatively, user-supplied formula can specified, formula limited generic variables W, Y, wi, yj, count, W1,..., WI, Y1,..., YJ.  three MRCV case, user-supplied formulas accepted. addition generic variables defined two MRCVs, formula may include generic variables Z, zk, Z1,..., ZK. add.constant positive constant added zero marginal cell counts. boot logical value indicating whether bootstrap resamples taken. B desired number bootstrap resamples. B.max maximum number bootstrap resamples.  Resamples least one item positive negative responses thrown ; genloglin uses first B valid resamples valid resamples number less B. print.status logical value indicating whether progress updates provided.  print.status = TRUE, status IPF algorithm printed every 5 iterations.  Upon completion IPF algorithm, progress bar appears documents progress bootstrap.

title: Model the Association Among Two or Three MRCVs — genloglin
text: — genloglin returns object class 'genloglin'. object list containing least following objects: original.arg, mod.fit, sum.fit, rs.results. original.arg list containing following objects: data: original data frame supplied data argument. : original value supplied argument. J: original value supplied J argument. K: original value supplied K argument. nvars: number MRCVs. model: original value supplied model argument. add.constant: original value supplied add.constant argument. boot: original value supplied boot argument. mod.fit list containing objects returned glm modifications described summary.genloglin. sum.fit list containing objects returned summary method class "glm" modifications described summary.genloglin. rs.results list containing following objects (see Appendix Bilder Loughin, 2007, detail): cov.mu: covariance matrix estimated cell counts. E: covariance matrix residuals. gamma: Eigenvalues used computing second-order Rao-Scott adjusted statistics. — boot = TRUE, primary list additionally includes boot.results, list containing following objects: B.use: number bootstrap resamples used. B.discard: number bootstrap resamples discarded due least one item positive negative responses. model.data.star: two MRCV case, numeric matrix containing 2Ix2J rows B.use+4 columns, first 4 columns correspond model variables W, Y, wi, yj, last B.use columns correspond observed counts resample.  three MRCV case, numeric matrix containing 2Ix2Jx2K rows B.use+6 columns, first 6 columns correspond model variables W, Y, Z, wi, yj, zk, last B.use columns correspond observed counts resample. mod.fit.star: two MRCV case, numeric matrix containing B.use rows 2Ix2J +1 columns, first 2Ix2J columns correspond model-predicted counts resample, last column corresponds residual deviance resample.  three MRCV case, numeric matrix containing B.use rows 2Ix2Jx2K+1 columns, first 2Ix2Jx2K columns correspond model-predicted counts resample, last column corresponds residual deviance resample. chisq.star: numeric vector length B.use containing Pearson statistics (comparing model saturated model) calculated resample. lrt.star: numeric vector length B.use containing LRT statistics calculated resample. residual.star: numeric matrix 2Ix2J rows (2Ix2Jx2K rows three MRCV case) B.use columns containing residuals calculated resample.

title: Model the Association Among Two or Three MRCVs — genloglin
text: genloglin function first converts raw data form can used estimation.  two MRCV case, reformatted data frame contains 2Ix2J rows 5 columns generically named W, Y, wi, yj, count.  three MRCV case, reformatted data frame contains 2Ix2Jx2K rows 7 columns generically named W, Y, Z, wi, yj, zk, count.  , model interest estimated calling glm function family argument specified poisson.  predictor variables, first level reference group (.e., 1 reference variables W, Y, Z, 0 reference variables wi, yj, zj). boot argument must equal TRUE order obtain bootstrap results genloglin method functions.

title: Model the Association Among Two or Three MRCVs — genloglin
text: Bilder, C. Loughin, T. (2007) Modeling association two categorical variables allow multiple category choices. Communications Statistics–Theory Methods, 36, 433–451.

title: Model the Association Among Two or Three MRCVs — genloglin

what: Create an Item Response Table or Data Frame — item.response.table
title: Create an Item Response Table or Data Frame — item.response.table
text: item.response.table function used summarize data arising one, two, three MRCVs.  one two MRCV cases, cross-tabulation positive negative responses (Wi, Yj) pair presented table data frame (Wi = W one MRCV case).  three MRCV case, cross-tabulation positive negative responses (Wi, Yj) pair presented conditional response Zk.

title: Create an Item Response Table or Data Frame — item.response.table
code: item.response.table(data, I, J, K = NULL, create.dataframe = FALSE)

title: Create an Item Response Table or Data Frame — item.response.table
text: data data frame containing raw data rows correspond individual item response vectors, columns correspond items W1, ..., WI, Y1, ..., YJ, Z1, ..., ZK (order). number items corresponding row variable W.  = 1 one MRCV case. J number items corresponding column variable Y. K number items corresponding strata variable Z. create.dataframe logical value indicating whether results presented data frame instead table.

title: Create an Item Response Table or Data Frame — item.response.table
text: create.dataframe = FALSE, item.response.table uses tables:tabular() function produce tables marginal counts. create.dataframe = TRUE, item.response.table returns information presents data frame.  one MRCV case, data frame contains rx2J rows 4 columns generically named W, Y, yj, count.  two MRCV case, data frame contains 2Ix2J rows 5 columns named W, Y, wi, yj, count.  three MRCV case, data frame contains 2Ix2Jx2K rows 7 columns named W, Y, Z, wi, yj, zk, count.

title: Create an Item Response Table or Data Frame — item.response.table

text: marginal.table function used summarize positive responses (joint positive responses multiple MRCVs) data arising one, two, three MRCVs. function essentially provides subset counts item.response.table function.

title: Create a Marginal Table — marginal.table
Create a Marginal Table — marginal.table
text: data data frame containing raw data rows correspond individual item response vectors, columns correspond items W1, ..., WI, Y1, ..., YJ, Z1, ..., ZK (order). number items corresponding row variable W.  = 1 one MRCV case. J number items corresponding column variable Y. K number items corresponding strata variable Z.

title: Create a Marginal Table — marginal.table
text: marginal.table function uses tables:tabular() function produce table containing positive counts.

title: Create a Marginal Table — marginal.table
code: # Create a marginal table for 1 MRCV # farmer.mtable.one <- marginal.table(data = farmer1, I = 1, J = 5) # farmer.mtable.one  # Create a marginal table for 2 MRCVs farmer.mtable.two <- marginal.table(data = farmer2, I = 3, J = 4) farmer.mtable.two #>                                                                 #>     y1             y2             y3             y4             #> w3 19    6.81      6    2.15     1     0.36     0     0.00      # Create a marginal table for 3 MRCVs farmer.mtable.three <- marginal.table(data = farmer3, I = 3, J = 4, K = 5) farmer.mtable.three #> $z1 #>                                                                 #>     y1             y2             y3             y4             #>     count   %      count   %      count   %      count   % what: Calculate Observed and Model-Predicted Odds Ratios for MRCV Data — predict.genloglin
title: Calculate Observed and Model-Predicted Odds Ratios for MRCV Data — predict.genloglin
text: predict.genloglin method calculates observed model-predicted odds ratios confidence intervals using results genloglin. uses asymptotic normal approximation confidence intervals observed model-predicted odds ratios, provides bootstrap approach estimating confidence intervals model-predicted odds ratios.

title: Calculate Observed and Model-Predicted Odds Ratios for MRCV Data — predict.genloglin
code: # S3 method for class 'genloglin' predict(object, alpha = 0.05, pair = "WY", print.status = TRUE, ...)

title: Calculate Observed and Model-Predicted Odds Ratios for MRCV Data — predict.genloglin
text: object object class "genloglin", produced genloglin function. alpha numeric value specifying desired alpha level confidence intervals. function provides two-sided (1-alpha)x100% confidence intervals. pair case three MRCVs, character string specifying pair items odds ratios calculated: "WY" (Wi, Yj) conditional Zk, "WZ" (Wi, Zk) conditional Yj, "YZ" (Yj, Zk) conditional Wi. print.status logical value indicating whether provide bootstrap progress updates. ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Calculate Observed and Model-Predicted Odds Ratios for MRCV Data — predict.genloglin
text: list containing least original.arg, .obs,   .model.asymp: original.arg: list containing original arguments supplied           genloglin. .obs: numeric matrix containing observed odds ratios           confidence intervals. .model.asymp: numeric matrix containing model-predicted odds           ratios confidence intervals using asymptotic normal approximation. boot = TRUE genloglin function, returned list additionally includes: boot.results: list containing bootstrap-related results           B.use, B.discard, .model.BCa.

title: Calculate Observed and Model-Predicted Odds Ratios for MRCV Data — predict.genloglin
text: Wald confidence intervals estimated model-based (see Appendix Bilder Loughin, 2007) observed (see Agresti, 2013, p. 70) odds ratios. bootstrap method also available, providing bias-corrected accelerated (BCa) confidence intervals model-predicted odds ratios. information BCa intervals, see Efron (1987). predict.genloglin function uses jackknife approximation estimate empirical influence values. Note: bootstrap confidence intervals available boot = TRUE original call genloglin function.

title: Calculate Observed and Model-Predicted Odds Ratios for MRCV Data — predict.genloglin
text: Agresti, . (2013). Categorical Data Analysis (3rd ed.). Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons. Bilder, C., & Loughin, T. (2007). Modeling association two categorical variables allow multiple category choices. Communications Statistics–Theory Methods, 36, 433-451. Efron, B. (1987). Better bootstrap confidence intervals. Journal American Statistical Association, 82, 171-185.

what: Steller Sea Lion Scat Data of Riemer, Wright, and Brown (2011) — sealion
title: Steller Sea Lion Scat Data of Riemer, Wright, and Brown (2011) — sealion
text: sealion data frame portion data analyzed Riemer, Wright, Brown (2011).  data represents types prey found Steller sea lion scats found mouth Columbia river August 2004 2007.  goal determine diet habits sea lions changed time.

title: Steller Sea Lion Scat Data of Riemer, Wright, and Brown (2011) — sealion
text: data frame contains following 12 columns: Column 1, labeled Date, corresponds date data collection. Two collection dates, 8/10/2004 8/7/2007, included data frame. Columns 2-12 correspond types prey found Steller sea lion scats.  Binary responses (1 = Present scat, 0 = present scat) provided category. prey1: Unidentified fish prey2: Pacific lamprey (Lampetra tridentata) prey3: Starry flounder (Platichthys stellatus) prey4: Pacific sardine (Sardinops sagax) prey5: Pacific herring (Clupea pallasii) prey6: Unidentified clupeid (family Clupeidae) prey7: Unidentified skate (family Rajidae) prey8: Northern anchovy (Engraulis mordax) prey9: Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) prey10: Pacific staghorn sculpin (Leptocottus armatus) prey11: Pacific hake (Merluccius productus)

title: Steller Sea Lion Scat Data of Riemer, Wright, and Brown (2011) — sealion
text: Riemer, S. D., Wright, B. E., Brown, R. F. (2011) Food habits Steller sea lions (Eumetopias jubatus) Oregon northern California, 1986-2007.  Fishery Bulletin, 109, 369–381.

title: Steller Sea Lion Scat Data of Riemer, Wright, and Brown (2011) — sealion
